column41: Let's say there's a bot that can run an interview and can manage projects, it can go through so many iterations in a month, so what's the points of us, I'm talking full universal basic income, we go back to philosophizing, like ancient greece, that the utopian version. the dystopian version is we can never trust anything we see again because we don't know who created it" QUOTE 15:09:10

column43:
Says google workspace is the most exciting thing currently: streamlines things, gives a good baseline, says human still needs to be involved to make final decisions

"I do get worried about, for a company how projects get priced and scheduled on the assumption that we should be using genAI. SO does analysis get cut down by half, does reporting get cut down by half because they assume that we should be using these tools. Whether that leads to increased workloads, whether the human brain can take on a project in such a small amount of time just because we have more tools. More tools doesn't equal my brain can immediately catch up with it" QUOTE 15:21:30

column6: Senior UX researcher, about 10.5 years
column10: Doom scrolling on twitter, keeping up with news with twitter and general news sites. I'm a sucker for binge watch of TV series. Anything on netflix, especially related to cooking, and I do like putting a bet on football and sometimes horse racing. Every couple weeks, online shopping, keeping up with messaging of people. Messaging apps, whatsapp. If they exclude leisure, everything is online for my job, online meetings, google workspace products, so that'll be a key part of the week.
column11: Keeping track, most of it through outlook in the office 365 space which will keep track of any meetings and research studies. Keep up to date on various documents on google drive and sharepoint, also combines this with physical lists. Tried online lists but get overwhelmed. I like being able to physically take things off as well, gives me a little dopamine hit whereas I don't get the same feeling from an online tool.
column12: 3, I consider keeping up with various tech updates and implementing with work, I'm good with that. Consider 2 and 1 being the person can code very well, but I've been able to build PCs and from a young age was the one in the family keeping the computer okay.
column14: Like the ability to find any answer quickly. Any bit of information be it I'm just interested in a fact, or I need to find a good pub or restaurant, it's all there. I love being able to keep up with various updates related to work or research or news quick. The physical analogues of that would be waiting for a monthly magazine to come out and the way tech progresses, that was out of date the first day it came out. Love the fact I can call my parents at any time. At the same time I do not like, because there's an infinite amount of time I could spend going through twitter or reddit, and it could easily take a huge chunk of my day and even though I get screen time alerts, I feel like it doesn't matter. Feel like I'm glued to a screen for workday, certain portions of my non-work day would be on the screen as well. Feel like it gets a hold of me and there's something else I could have done instead. It's almost like replacing certain dopamine hits in my brain which is a bit black mirror-ie
column17: Chatgpt, just because it's the one everyone is talking about and that's something I use quite a lot. It's also imagine generation like dali, to a lesser extent, but mostly chatgpt
column20: I think it had a certain novelty impact when it came out. I've been using gpt before, I was playing around with it but mostly as a bit of fun and doing a bit of written research on it. I think chatgpt is quite formative in that. Suddenly it's actually useful whereas the other things were more fun, this has a more practical aspect, that's the main difference. M: you were aware of and used gpt before chatgpt? P: Yeah, was using gpt 2 and 3 mostly and a couple older chatbox variations that were so machine like they were funny. But chatgpt became useful and more good that it's not as funny anymore. M: what were some use cases of gpt 2? P: The games we'd play, we'd get various chatbox, we did a game called the daddying game, just like the dating game where you have to pick one of three people you cannot see to go on a date with where you had to choose which chatbox you'd want to be your father. We wrote a paper in 2021 or 22 on how chatbox discuss sexuality and gender identity and gpt 2 or 3 was markedly different from the others. We'd use that in a playful and exploratorive sense.
column21: M: how view of internet has changed since chatgpt arrive, P: probably 10, changed viewpoint in that it can be 10% worse. Because of gen AI explotion it makes me more distrustful of content because people can just generate it straight away. Now I've had more experience with long form text with chatgpt, it makes me more suspicious and think eventually the internet will be loads of chatbox talking to each other, and we're just human puppets curating content generated by machines. Students write papers with chatgpt, teachers mark with chatgpt, people manage relationships with chatgpt. Although it's useful for me I can see how it's societally detrimental.
column23: n/a
column28: I used it a few times a week, not everyday. I like it for ideation. For example I'm giving a talk at a conference and know where to find talking points and have some, but I just want more ideas. That's really useful, it's great for producing a quick list and you can focus on some. Text summarization is hit and miss, you need a lot of prompt engineering and specific ways to sayhow to handle the data. Mostly for ideation and occasionally for summarizing. Also for rephrasing things. Or can you write the blog for me and I can make edits.
column30: LinkedIn because the people I follow all over this and a few have their own media outlets. There's so much out there I want to focus on people I know who've been leading the conversation on conversational AI and occasionally I'll see a link to a video. M: do you find everyday you're looking for new sources because it's happening so quickly? P: with gpt 4 having just been announced it's probably everyday, but as we get used to gpt 4 it might be a couple times a week. But I found out loads of things you can do on gpt 4 on linkedin and twitter
column33: There's 3 of 10 who use it more than others. Others have been using it to create draft mod guides for example to see if it works. We've been talking about it as a team since it came out. And one colleague did a presentation written by chatgpt to make the point the world is changing. I use it more often than most team members.
column34: not yet Have ongoing discussions on how we might integrate it into the team. No real strict policy that I know of. I know chatgpt has an opt out feature so whatever you put in doesn't get added to the data base. Apart from that we're still on the testing side. M: do you think at some point companies needing to have policy to regulate usage? P: Maybe, training definitely. I think training is part of the skill set on how to use gen AI effectively and appropriately. I don't know if policy will come out maybe something passed on by a client. Don't know there's a point where we can't run certain things through chatgpt. Since it's moving so quick, especially with gpt4 coming out, I think that might be the one that creates policy discussions because you're talking about images as well. I know there's discussion about legality of using gen AI images especially if too similar to another work
column35: Unsure
column37: I have some confidence in that I've seen some changes in terms of output. I've used chatgpt and asked for similar research projects to the one I've done, it spits out 10 examples, none of the people exist, and not all the journals exist, and the titles of the project don't exist, but gpt 4 starts providing accurate sources. M: like a potential bibliography? P: yes, it says this thing happened and I can prove it with this source. There are some changes I've sen and it brings back to people have recognized it needed to be changed and people have implemented it. So it comes back to people. M: so in the span of a few months you've seen changes to make it more trustworthy? P: yes
column39: I see two angles. One it's good in that you can do things quicker. You can summarize data really quick, or feed in a bit of transcript, so you could put your multilingual transcript data and say find similarities or differences, etc. M: In a single go? P: Yeah, 25,000 words and it'll spit some things out. But at the same time I don't know how much I trust it. If I'm going to have to go back and check it should I just do it myself anyway? And there's the idea that will we need new skill sets to incorporate gen AI. I think yes. You have to adapt to the industry, so I think it'll require a bit of retraining and learning how to use these. Google showcased their gen AI changes to workspace and it's all these features you see in Dali and chatgpt in workspace. It's summarizing meeting, create a debrief based on text and can create a presentation out of it. It could speed up the research process but we might also need to take on more work quicker cause we are expected as researchers as well. You can do this in 10% of the time and now your project goes from a month to a week. How that all manifests is a mixed bag.
column40: No, I think the heart of user research is people connecting with one another. Us with researchers connecting with clients and understanding what they want, connecting with our participants to understand what they mean, and connecting back to the clients. You're not going to sit there and have a kickoff meeting with gen AI and not a readout where you see "I'm going to spend 5 minutes on this cause you think this is interesting". I don't think gen AI saying "I think it means this". I think it can describe, but not interpret and I don't think it can run interviews yet. So there's always a possibility. Who knows where it'll go in a year, then you add 10 years to that, but if you have in commercially available quantum computers in the process, then in 20 years, I don't know. I think the singularity might be coming.
column41: It's not quite the matrix, maybe more in 30-50 years, but if at a certain point tech becomes so powerful, including quantum computing, then why do we need us to do things. So what if we do get replaced for jobs, if there's a bot that can run interviews and manage projects, then let them do it. So what's the point in us? Talking full on universal basic income and we go back to playing instruments and philosophising, basically ancient Greece in the utopian version. The dystopian version is we can never believe anything we see or hear again because we don't know who created it. I think ultimately it needs human involvement to be ethical and legislative measure before it gets out of control. But it's good for quicker reports, so it's a give and take. M: where's your excitement now? P: 4, excited but nervous but ultimately believe in people as a collective to do the right thing.
column42: At the moment yes [see it as negative] because you see certain signals like Microsoft fired the ethical AI team out of openAI and they're usually very good at inclusivity and ethics, you hear about how chatgpt came to be and it's through outsourcing on places like Kenya with people working on very little money and being exposed to weird and harmful text-based content. I think it needs a balance from academic communities, possibly legislation as well, the EU is pretty on top of legislation for AI initiatives. I'm part of a group who try to create ethical standards for AI. It lacks a moral compass and the company bought openAI firing the people who are meant to be safeguarding it.
column43: The google workspace is most exciting for me. Think it streamlines the more tedious aspects, don't think it should be the final product, always need the human aspect but it's an exciting time to steamline some of that stuff. I do get worried about... how a company how projects get priced and sent on on the assumption that we should be using gen AI, does analysis get cut down by half because they assume we should be using these tools. And whether that leads to increased workloads and whether the human brain can take on a project in such a small amount of time and easily switch because we have more tools. More tools does not mean my brain can easily catch up with this. Whether that impacts that aspect of work

Wasn't able to give ChatGPT input on incorrect answers (GPT gave wrong address to Hankook office)

column40:
I have to mention language barriers
They've been tested in English language but for Korean markets and content from Korea, there have been issues interpreting foreign language 
There is nuance and literature that only can be understood by humans
QUOTE 20:07 "What I feel is that Google or other generative AI wasn't able to collect enough data from all these web activities happening in the foreign platforms so that makes its progress a little slower for Korean language at least"
 
 There has to be person interaction and language interaction where the machine cannot replace just yet, the language barrier will make it challenging for generative AI to run qualitative study end to end
 
 They have made core activity of translating Korean into English, they never use Google Translate either Korean into English or vice versa because they use Papago with machine translator that works better and we were hoping to see an improvement with this ChatGPT which I did not find as much
 
 QUOTE 21:58 "The ChatGPT if you write in Korean didn't give us any correct answers at all...not even the address of our company"
 
 We told chatGPT it was wrong but then it didn't work so it's not as active
 The address it gives it real but is not correct and it still gave that after a couple of days

column37: I haven't tested chatgpt 4, only used 3.5 and I would never use it for work, not at all confident, so 1 or 2. But I know the time isn't far for me to rely on the tool. Haven't tried gpt 4, but I know it's much better. For simple task like data cleaning, I'm sure I'll soon be able to scale to 9 or 10
column40: I have to mention language barrier. For Korean market, any content from Korea has the issue of intepreting the Korean language to foreign language. That's one of the reasons google wasn't major player in Korean market because of the language nuance that only Koreans can understand as a human. I feel gen AI wasn't able to collect enough data happening on other platforms. That makes progress slower for Korean language. Being a qual researcher interacting with end user, it has to be the person interaction that the machine cannot replace just yet. That barrier will make it challenging for AI to run end-to-end for Korean language. M: has team used the translation? P: We do a lot of it, one of the core activities we're trying. You use google translate, but we don't do that because we have papago which translates much better. We were hoping to see much improvement from chatgpt which I did not find as much. From testing, if we write in Korean chapgpt didn't give any correct information. I don't recall any information I searched that was true if I used Korean. That's a huge problem, we were trying to get the machine to learn it was wrong. If we tell repetitively it was wrong this is the correct info, we were trying to add it to the output but it didn't work. One of the first questions we asked was for the office address and it gave a wrong thing. This hallucination effect will impact people to leave chatgpt.
column41: I'm nervous, I know it won't come as quickly as we expect. In the next year, I don't think anything will really change, it's time for people to apply the tool in their businesses, but they might not immediately start buying for the license. But they'll start having employees getting training for the tool. It's become one of the alternative options for clients to choose from. My clients are not as conservative and are willing to try new things, but I don't think they'll be willing to use chatgpt for their analysis. One year wouldn't change so much, but 3 years from now people will start commissioning projects using gen AI and 5 years things will change everything. Before gen AI we would programming automated analysis reports for tracking studies, we had programs that read data from table and visualize it on graph and write a few words. We will start implementing those tools into our practices, not as close as 3 years, but things will change entirely in 5 years

column6: Managing director, more than 20 years
column9: I cannot live without it. Used to stay in China, it's a very convenient place, but cannot stand not having access to the internet. When doing research it's a headache without the freedom of having the internet.
column10: Social media, browser looking for info are most predominant, do not play online games. Work and social with friends
column11: Before the chatbox, google is definitely something I would go for information, and sometimes libraries to look for papers. Communicating with clients, in China it's WeChat. Even within the team we have wechat, right now I'm not in the same country as my team so it's very useful. Every time we have a company or project, the client will create a wechat group so we can communicate and during the streaming they'll ask questions. That's the most dominant platform or internet things I'm using in daily life
column14: I think it gives us access to everything happening in the world without going out or talking to people. It's a way of getting new information and getting connected to the world, you just need a screen and you can virtually go everywhere or get everything.
column17: Neural network. When I was study we had to study neural networking, at the time we had to write the programming and train the computer, it was 20 years ago. When I was 20 something, that's the first time I got to play with the AI thing or the concept. At the time we wrote the coding and gave the computer a bunch of coffee cups to do neural network training and then gave the computer other cups to have the computer determine whether it's a coffee cup or not. The idea of AI or machine learning, whatever the algorithm, the idea is the same. We have an input, a data base, and a certain algorithm and we have the output. It's interesting to see how it's gone a long way
column19: Not long ago, about a month. It was on a social media post. I saw it and gave it a try and started to play with it. Now I use chatgpt very often. M: everyday? P: yes M: what's the last time you used it? P: an hour ago, M: what did you do with it? P: I was sending an email to a client, used another chatbox claude or sage, told the chatbox my intention what I wanted to say and can you write this for me and it gave me something, and I gave corrections. I think it's quite useful for us where English is not our native language so sometimes we make grammatical errors, minor errors. I think this is a very quick way to do proof reading, or having another way of saying things. M: do you give prompts in Chinese too? P: yes I have M: when did you start using this tool? P: after chatgpt, I started with chatgpt and then started this one. I have a friend, who works with Apple, because this app is not open source yet, and he shared it with us, it actually combines 4 or 5 chatbox, including chatgpt. I switch between chatbox to see which one is better, because I know some are better at dealing with multiple languages, some better at logic. M: and this tool brings them all together? P: Yes
column20: Yes, because the chatbox, Siri thing, is not a new idea, it was already existing. At the time it was very limited, not as natural as if talking to a person. What makes it different from other AI things is that it's very easy, like you're talking to a person. It's really like you're chatting. I think that's the underlying feeling. M: has the way you use the internet changed? P: I think I use google last, Google has too much ads there now. And google lacks the interaction like you're talking to someone. And when you ask google something you have to be very precise. I don't have to be very precise [with chatgpt], because when I ask on Google I have to be very precise. Sometimes my way of thinking is not very organized, that's what I find fascinating about chatgpt. I use chatgpt or chatbox as another person or assistant, sometimes I want to discuss something and type that I'm thinking about something but not sure how to phrase it, and it'll give me something back. It can help me to continue my work, like a person by my side. This is something Google cannot do, of course it makes mistakes. When we first started we found it cannot tell whether 7 is a prime number. M: what about the other chatbox you use? P: Sometimes correct, sometimes not. It's like a person, sometimes it makes mistakes. The algorithm behind it is like logic, so it generates the answer based on the logic. When you ask something about right or wrong you might not get a correct answer but if you ask about some phenomena or something they can describe I think that's something they're better at
column21: n/a
column23: 8, still not an expert.
column31: It'll make our work faster. Like quickly generating a new work cloud, or summarize or keywords, or generate some images. I think those things, it's useful. I was chatting with my team and showed them the experiment we're doing with chatgpt. In some projects, the participant has to image putting a device in my room or maybe in another style, would it fit better. They have to use their imagination, but with this kind of tool, the image doesn't have to be very accurate, we can just type in the words and something comes out. Sometimes it'll be easier for people to carry on the discussion when they look at something physical and tangible. It'll definitely make things faster when we use this tools in a smart way. M: would client expect more or cheaper from you? P: Not sure, but when chatgpt came out, I was talking to a client and she was telling me they were having the same discussion about whether the job of a researcher will be replaced. Now we can still be certain that the mindset of research won't be replaced, it can help us do analysis. The machine cannot know how to get insights out, I think that's what clients value most. It's possible that clients will say "hey you can do things faster" but it's hard to say. It's a reasonable argument if clients say so.

Negative thing I think rely on it too much. Like wikipedia, I tested it once because anyone can edit [wikipedia] and I watched the interview of the CEO saying that they can correct it within 3 minutes. So I tested it, one was a super big celebrity like Michael Jackson and the other was Rick Springfield who is famous but not, and Nietzsche, a famous philosopher and this guy who played the Wonka guy in the chocolate factory. Like Michael Jackson I couldn't even edit, he's so famous, I couldn't edit his page. Rick Springfield, I edited and received a warning within 3 minutes that they would ban my IP if I continued. For Nietzsche I wrote something that's very hard to judge if right or wrong and it stayed there. It was incorrect, but stayed for a couple weeks and I got another warning email. And the other actor I wrote a movie that doesn't even exist and after 15 years it's still there. Internet makes people stupid, they don't really search wide. I think people get stupider and stupider from the convenience.

column40: Thinking about how quickly tech advances, in 5-10 years time, I think it'll be doable. Most of the research is pretty straightforward, we're asking someone questions they give a reply, and we summarize the reply. Collecting basic data and summarizing and seeing trend and segmenting the users, I think the gen AI will be able to do in a matter of time.
column41: In 5 years, I thought I'd be the last generation that would escape from being controlled by AI, work like a human and retire like a human, but when chatgpt came out I thought "I thought I could retire first, but there's no way I can escape this either." In 5-10 years I wonder what people will be doing. M: impact on printing press, loom? P: something as big as the printing machine, it's a huge comet really.
column42: I don't see it as Terminator kind of world, but I see it in a negative way because it makes people think less on their own. Is it convenient, yes, but it makes them less human in a way. I don't see AI taking over but it makes people think less, which is sad. M: what happens to thinkers in this world? P: I don't know. I can't even picture what the world will be like in 10 years with this kind of thing. I think it's going to be just artisans and craftsmanship. Those people will be more valued, which is in a good way. I think today the wealth is distributed in a screwed up way, like teachers should be paid more cause it's such and important job, but people in finance make a lot of money but what are they doing. Essential workers should be paid more, it might even help more with gen AI, those things could be taken by AI and essential work needs to be done by humans. It could work in a positive way in that sense. M: where it reaches critical mass and turns the other way. Like people going back and learning how to farm. P: yeah
column43: I think I have to read more, I have to make sure I'm up to date with all happening. I haven't done much research on it, I'm just using it, but because it's something that can directly impact work, it's something I should look into, see its strengths, how we can use it and take advantage of it before others do. It's something I need to do. M: I see the value of someone who is a purist, hasn't been influenced by outside info but just using the tool. P: It's just amazing. Do I like it? Not really, I'm an analogue person, I don't even use a digital watch. For a person like me it's just way too much. But it is what it is, I think it'll be more advanced, you can't stop it, so finding ways to live with it and how to use it in a smart way. To use it you need to know what it is and what it can do, so I need to do more research on it.

Likes to do currency conversions, very detailed

Likes the way chat gpt interacts w her and gives her info - for example asked about currency amounts and likes how chat gpt breaks it down and the depth, interactions are a lot more engaging and more personalized compared to google, something she can relate to more than google

For current online studies, chat gpt can pick up non sense answers and promt for rephrasing - very useful and let ppl spend less time cleaning data bc its already clean from the data collection phase

M - did that help you? P - yes.

Feeding data in so its only using its intelligence to analyze what is there. if that is the case then you can trust that data as well. disadvantages, doesn't have any emotional iq. doesnt understand sarcasm or context from the past where you are connecting the dots. using it to get information, it can give info very quickly but i should still use my own intelligence and not take it at face value, doing research on my own.

M - level of satisfaction? P - 5, it had an answer but missed nuance.

column37:
3-4

says the idea of trusting it entirely is too simple, and if something is so simple there's a catch to it, says there is a danger to closing oneself of to other resources

is not sure chatGPT is cross referencing its sources, doesn't know the extent of its bias

is still uncertain about the sources of chatGPTs information, especially relating to its knowledge base of Africa, assumes much of its information is sourced from English/Western sources

has determined that chat GPT cannot contextualize beyond surface level meanings to actual uses in specific countries, and considers this a limitation that a researcher can then push beyond with other sources

would rate level of satisfaction as a 5

chatGPT has answers to give but they are superficial
column39:
main concern is that global clients will look at AI tools are a way to shortcut processes in the research cycle, that clients will come to a project with assumptions having used chatGPT and ask only for tools to run sessions then take the feedback for their own processing

fears clients will cut the research cycle down to data collection and do their own analysis, which will make research less local and less contextual
column41:
says we may be headed towards holograms

based on developments in four months with AI says in six months could be even greater changes

sees in the future it will be necessary to improve education because we are introducing more complex technologies, kids will need to learn to do research without falling into misinformation with AI

sees AI replacing many sources of information, not jobs per se, sees integration of AI tools into businesses to replace lots of manpower with faster AI with a person tracking it to do exactly what it needs

says 20 years into the future there could be hologram researchers walking around in the field
column42:
not sure, says its useful right now because we're under the impression that it gives everything we want without considering all the risks it comes with

thinks it could be positive but that it depends on properly evaluating the ethical dimension of things right now

thinking right now about the future the outlook is more negative, concerned about how kids will be learning, whether they will actually be using their brains to find and summarize information, give opinions about it, is concerned that if there are tools that provide summarized information already members of society may not develop the intellect to develop their own opinions through their own research
column43:
says researchers are interested not only in the impact on the research field but also the impacts on other fields

says AI is not new but the manner of presentation with chatGPT is new and scarier

column30: doing desk research, looking for trusted articles more journalist than academic. then also looking for videos, would go to tiktok first. see what the news is talking about. like to ask ai about itself and compare what everyone says.

column32: can be very efficient but only if you know how to use it and provide questions. you need to be good at it or else you get low quality answers. it saves time for me. know i dont need to check it so much since it learns quickly, so it provides freedom. negative side is related to confidence, dont know how much i trust it. what is being done with our data. everything must be scrubbed or out of context. theres some learning process and sometimes dont trust it at all.
column33: Team using chatgpt and some other transcription tools as well. using a tool (tactic) that license will expire soon. but it saves files to drive so everyone can see. concerns about leaking data so stopping using it. will be implementing google cloud ai for transcription, aiming to be fully using that in next month.
column34: Yes one guideline is do not use free stuff. if you want to try use test forms. safe conscious but close to paranoid. if using everything google based like the safety and all the systems are connected. so translator is the goal. google translate is accurate but doesnt learn that fast. when using ai, it understands context but google translate requires more interaction.

column32:
Advantages: Efficiency "can be very efficient but only if you know how to use it. It can be very inefficient if you don't know how to ask the question." "Gives me freedom" (to do more).
Disadvantages: Confidence, "I don't know how much I trust it. Who knows what they're doing with our data." Notes that there are concerns about safety and making sure the information is scrubbed before putting it into the system. "I do a pretty fine scrubbing and take things out of context when I use it."

column40: Yes, "for sure"

Advantages: It can be helpful with writing to help "reformat" or "think differently", coding, anything relatively mechanical that doesn't require a lot of "thought or context"
Disadvantages: Working around ethics and where data comes from. "It doesn't think like a human, there's an illusion of that, but you have to have enough knowledge and context yourself to know how to use it... It doesn't have the entire context and that requires vigilance"

column6: Current title is research ops lead, started working as researcher from 2008. Started from junior researcher and moved to senior. For 1 and half years, moved more towards research ops, looking for ways to apply it at client side which is more explorative. You need to see how to apply it as consultant, because usually it's easeir when you're part of the company
column9: We're almost always online, right now I'm working from home. During COVID we started to use it even more because we're all connected all the time and on meetings to collaborate with people. During work, for me a particular situation I'm living in a different country than my family, so I use internet, it's a useful way to connect with people. Especially for connecting, it plays a big role and we don't even understand how big role it plays for many ways. Thinking about my daughter for her it's normal she can look for videos or look it up all the time, when we were young we had to wait till it was available on TV or something. Especially, everything is available immediately, the knowledge you can look it up immediately. I think it's difficult to imagine a world without this possibility. You're not really thinking about it what's possible, seems almost normal right now that everything is almost immediately available and you can connect like you were doing interviews with Nigeria, in China. There might be some problems with internet connection sometimes, but on the other hand, we were all connected and that's really powerful.
column12: Yeah. Well I understand, I use tech. I'm not the person that when something new comes out I immediately buy it. I know it but not immediately use it. M: on scale of 1-10, 1 being paper, book, 10 being always on top of latest trends, where are you? P: Let's say an 8, still towards the higher end, from generation adapats and also for work, it's important to stay up to date. There's people when things come out they immediately buy or try it out, depends a little bit
column14: What I like and don't like? I think like it's the way it's an easy way to connect to people. What I don't like, I think the disadvantage is that you know it's always available, it can be a little, not addictive. Like your phone it's always available, especially when playing with my daughter I like not to touch it because then it seems like you're distracted. I think that's a little bit the distructive part. If you don't have phone or anything available you're concentrated on other things. Especially you grab a book and start reading right now, the tentative is to look something up on your phone, so I think that's the disadvantage.
column15: I think it has been, AI is not new. There's already years that people are working on it and they apply it. Right now it becomes even more easy to apply it or more graspable for people that they understand what the power is of it and what you can do with it. Maybe in the beginning it feels like something that is powerful, but right now it's easy to see the examples of what they can do with it but also more practical applied. So it's not only maybe... a person at home can use it in some way for him or her to be helpful instead of more higher level. So that's what I see a little bit, a difference right now.
column17: I would say it's of course artificial intelligence, but generative that it can, so it generates content or it can generate things. Literally that's what comes to mind because that's how you translate it. It's not only the AI but also the word to generate, can generate things. It creates, creation comes to mind.
column19: I think it was around, I don't rememer anymore if it was around Christmas or something, but it would be the last months or so. Right now we're March, so maybe November/December. M: remember context? P: I think there were a lot of articles, like when chatGPT was launched there some many articles. It became really a bust. You look on the internet and find things like people apply, start talking about it, how you can use it, etc. Basically that's it, more the news, online news. I read articles on LinkedIn for example or work-related contracts, I think that's when I started more reading it or seeing how you could use it.
column20: Yeah, I was excited to try it out. Was mostly curious how difficult it would be to start using it. There's quite some technology. It's different but the world of the metaverse or the crypti, crypto baluta these are all technology of the years, but sometimes it's not easy to get into it. Crypto valuta for example, I think we tried it out just to understand the process but in order to apply there's many steps you need to go through in order to create the account to do it. It's not so easy, not every person can say I want to open it, tomorrow I do this and it's done. Same with the metaverse, there are things you can easily do, there are a few programs you can easily do. But if you really want to go into it, you have to create this account, you also need to have your crypto valuta for some things. It's complex. I thinnk that was the first thing, right now is this something that you... I don't know, just to understand is this something easy. It's fine to access it. That would be the main difference, if it's easily accessible a lot of people will adapt to it. I dont' feel, the crypto valuta for example, a lot of people are also there, but it's not like the total population or most has adopted it. Same with the metaverse, you hear things, but it's not like the... not yet, you never know. Right now with the generative AI I see some things, it's easier for people to use it. There's many things going on, there's not one example, it's many things you can apply it.
column21: 7. For me it really depends, if it's work related or personal life related. For work, I'm really interested, but personal life I don't care that much. Maybe yes, but I don't see that much. I'm fine. But for work, it can really be helpful.
column23: Yes, I'm used it. Looking at research for translation, transcriptions, sometimes for generating pictures, photos and the other day, a week ago, since I'm doing research, I'm often looking into tools and stuff to stay up to date on the new features and I was in a call with Miro the collaborative tool. They just launched but the AI is in beta version. I saw what it can do and was really... that would be very powerful. Creating in research work or workshops you might have, see if in one click they generate the summary of it. That's really powerful or creating, diagrams, mind maps and these kinds of things with ideas. That's where I can see it's really powerful. Like in my personal life I'm not going to do this kind of things. That's I see more difference in interest in work and personal life. Maybe I don't see yet how it could be helpful on a personal level instead of work.
column30: Usually read articles most on medium, on linkedin. This kind of platforms where you can read it, talk to your colleagues about it because they use it and then you can learn from each other. That's more like word to... us saying it. Not reading it ourselves, but just learning from others.
column31: Transcriptions, translations, generating photos,Creating summaries and mind maps,
column32:
I think with every tech you still have to think yourself. It's not the same with the translation, it's really good but still read through it to see if it makes sense. It's not about trust, I believe that maybe it's even better than professional translator, but the same with the post-its that can reduce, but still... it can help you with the step of analyzing, but still I think there's space for the human to do some analysis like what we do as researchers. It's to find the right balance, where you can use it to reduce the work and where you know you need to step in to do define analysis or conclusions. 

Useful for work, disadvantages: can help with step of analyzing, but there's still space for the human to do analysis, looking for right balance for reducing work and whne you need to step in QUOTE 15:27
column33: In our company we have a team that's working on AI but in general they use it to develop bots and AI. We have a team dedicated to it. So what we did about a month ago, sometimes we have sharing sessions in the company, somebody presents something and then we talk about it. So we did it on the topic of generative AI, so everyone hears about it, just to understand a little better and also to discuss a little how we would use it and what would be the effect. For your own work, but as consultants we're also working for clients so they will also be asking us hwo they could use it or we could be involved in projects or something like that. That's how we started the company talking about it.
column34: Right now, I haven't heard any regulations yet that they implied. We do have some codes on security and data privacy, etc. I think right now it's still in a phase that there's no clear boundaries or set of rules yet. We haven't had any specific guidelines of saying you cannot use it. It's more like trial and error to see how it can help you and if it can help you in your work that's fine. But of course, it's more out of regulation. There's no strict rules yet. Of course you have to apply general rules to do ethical and safe research. That's the normal procedures. We haven't set any rules that you cannot use it to generate image or generate data or for translation, transcriptions. More simulated like try it out because it's new tech. It's what we would need to use in our work and as consultants know about it. Also use it so you get to know it better. It's more like simulated to try it out and then talk about it and see how it can support work. But there's no real set of guidelines yet. Apart from the if you're talking about data, GDPR still applies, copyright with images. We have to buy them in order to use them. The same rules apply as SP4.
column35: Not yet, but anticipates or hopes for one
column37: Yeah, I've seen translations, like before you could use google translate, it's even better sometimes than this. So I think trust is quite high, but for me, I'm more still one to have the control, not the control, but I still check it. I'm not 100% okay, this is translated, this is fine. But more or less because... As I would normally do, but I see that quality is very high, so I think there's a moment will be like you can... the trust will increase over time if you use it more often and you see the quality is really high. Right now I'm still, I need to use it more often to get more confident about it. M: confidence on scale of 1-10? P: For what I use it, I'd say quite high. The quality is very good. 8, something like that. 8,9, 11
column39: I think it can support research. It wouldn't, I wouldn't be afraid that it would substitute the researchers. It can support in translation, analysis of a lot of data, but still I don't see it like it could do the moderation. You need the non-verbal behaviors are very important, the human to human relation and I think the final analysis, that's still something a human needs to do to understand the context. You can analyze the data, you can draw conclusions, but in order to see how you can apply it, you need to understand many aspects. You have the business, the human aspect, you have the context. I think you still need the researcher to do this final step. I don't think that can be replaced, but a lot of things can go more quicker for some research. Building a protocol, it takes time right now, it would be much quicker to make changes during prototypes. AI can write code, right? You can say... even researchers certain times can do certain things because you don't need developer. Things can go quicker, I don't think it can replace the research. I don't feel there's a problem there. It can support many things. Of course there will be a lot of research on the topic, there's still a joke there as well. And to make it user friendly and all the applications. There's many applications there as well, so it can open up new fields, that's interesting.
column40: I don't see the two phases. The thing I see that's difficult is if you do moderated research. If unmoderated, it could maybe do it automatically. but the moderated, I think the face to face contact. I think you need a human to interpret the verbal and nonverbal communication. There's facial analysis in these things, but still I think there it's diffivult to really substitute. In the prep and analysis part I can see that it's getting replaced. Like I said, the final part, the conclusion of the conclusion, maybe you need someone, a researcher or human to do that final part. To put it into context and see many aspects together. Sometimes if there's tradeoffs, we have decisions, maybe certain solution is better for the business and another is better for the user. What decision would AI make? It's difficult, you need to give it... it's almost like not an ethical decision. Do you give priority to business or person. How would AI decide. Certain things it's better if a human would do that. Because it's not always based on data that you make certain decisions.
column41: That's really hard
column42: That's a difficult thing. On the one hand I'm really excited about it, but there's also the side effects. Especially for myself, I'm an adult, I can decide on it. I think it's more, for myself I see the perspective more on the positive side. I think for children, it can be quite dangerous. Or not dangerous, but they are... everything is open right? People that cannot, that don't have the... Like smaller children, they don't know what is good and what is not good. So for them it's more difficult to decide, I think there should be regulations, education on it. For me that's more the negative side. For myself, I see the positive side, I think I can be very interesting new ways of working, shopping, connecting to people. I see that, can be interested. For children, I see the negative side. I'm also a little bit worried on that and how that will evolve. My daughter is 3, in 10 years I think it'll be a huge difference as she's 13. How will it look like? You need to protect a little bit. So it's 2 sides. I have mixed feelings. I cannot say I'm so excited, but yeah.

column6: Founder and managing director, has been a researcher for 15 years
column9: The sentence that best describes that is I don't know what I did with my life before internet. I remember 1988 first time I got connected to the internet and 1997 and I still have the feeling of permanent discovering everything. I feel like a student learning a lot of things everyday. Of course, the more time the less learning in terms of... I discover a lot of things, but... Let me think how to explain. The more new technologies get attention of the people, for example AI, I have a feeling that okay, you keep learning like the first time. And for me it's impossible to think, to imagine my life without internet. Absolutely impossible.
column11: My background as a researcher starts because in university we call it cyber research in social work and after social work I studied sociology. Meaning social science are in the roots of my diploma. When I was in university I did not have internet access, that's an important point. I was this guy at the library all the time. Meaning, as a researcher, I found on internet the big place to stay because the possibility, the chance to access everything I needed. I remember my first partial paid job, I was like google engineering. Meaning I worked in a foundation, non profit, and my job was just search on google. Because everyone was older than me, there were people asking me, requesting all the time, can you search in the internet this or that all the time. Because they didn't know how to approach to search on google. Because until 1998, 1999, the tool discover things on the internet was yahoo or antavista, directories. Not asking to the machine with the texting, we call prompt. Before we call how to search in the internet. That's the feeling I have as a researcher. I grew up as a researcher asking google, asking search engines. And today, when I realized what is this chatGPT everyone is talking about, I feel I have to start to learn again, because everything I learned before is ok, but now it's time to rethink everything I know. To keep growing as a researcher of course.
column12: Absolutely yes. Considering that I never had a computer until I was, maybe 25 years when I had my first computer. I only knew how to switch on the electricity. I had no training with computers, everything I learned I learned by myself. Since that moment everything around my personal and professional life, turned around technology. I don't consider myself a tech guy because I don't care how the technology works. This is stuff for engineers or developers, I only care about the results and how people can deal with the technology, with the devices, not the tech. I try every kind of devices I can. M: on scale of 1-10, 1 being you can plug your computer, 10 being the extremem end of that? P: 8 or 9
column14: Things I like, everything. It's difficult to find things I don't like relatedthe internet. Maybe a thing I don't like, I don't know if it's related to the internet or not is connectivity. Connectivity is the reasons because people could not reach the internet. But internet as a concept, as a tool is fantastic, it's wonderful. I don't know what we do with our lives before the internet. I am absolutely deeply about that. If we speak about how people use internet, of course, there's a lot of bad habits and bad stability on the internet. All of this, say a knife, you could use a knife to cut bread, giving bread to your kids, but you can use the knife to kill the neighbor. It's not the knife, it's what you do with the knife. With the internet it's the same, of course we find a lot of really really bad stuff with the internet, but the good things we can reach thanks to the internet are bigger than the bad stuff. Because human beings it's impossible to, it's difficult to separate our behavior will be good and bad, same thing. But with the internet I think gives us better stuff than bad stuff.
column15: At the very beginning it was like a movie. Like a movie, the car is talking to you, the fridge is talking to you, the watch is talking to you. You have a conversation with the mirror, you can see the news in the mirror or talk with the mirror in the bathroom. But when I experienced the first approach for example with chatGPT I was really, it's like magic. Last year, I think like wow, is it true or this is just a demo and the demo is really really great? Because I think that this chat box is talking to me, it's replying in an accurate way the things I'm asking about. So the first reply I can share with you is wow, it's the best description. After that I can imagine that maybe have been using AI before that it wasn't transparent. I didn't notice that I've been using AI but today we have chatGPT and things like that. I have another kind of feeling, it's like it's clear, it's more true than before. It's like wow I can touch that and I can feel it in a different way than before. Before I guess I got the benefits, but now I'm experiencing, it's different for me.
column20: It was in chatGPT because suddenly a client started talking about chatGPT in terms of be careful because this tool is going to quit our job. This was the argument and they were showing several examples of using, just asking you are a famous writer please describe whatever with whatever style and then chatGPT start replying. When I realized I can ask in Spanish instead of English and it works the same way I was like "wow, this is really magic". For me, English is not my mother tongue. I learned English only 10 years ago, before I didn't speak. And for me the language is still a pain, so yes experiencing a tool I can speak, it doesn't matter the language I use to request the machine and the machine reply. Wow this is like magic. Really I feel I'm from the province. Like it's incredible. It was with chatGPT just asking simple stuff. Hey can you tell me when the human beings went to the moon, this kind of stuff. Then I started in a deep, had to explain deep work with chatGPT trying to understand how it works. What kind of requests I put into the chatGPT. And today I'm using chatgpt as a tool tot start my work. Not to finish the work, just start to give me an idea about something and then I finish because sometimes I try to get confused the machine because I ask something I already know it's not true, but I pretend to request, chatGPT really has a creative mind and it doesn't matter if it's true or not, she replies. There is a space to train there.
column21: Obviously a 10
column23: Basically it's not my main tool, maybe 50% of the time I am experiencing, I'm trying, I'm researching how the tool can help me. How the tool can give me support. And 50% of the time I'm training the technology to get a result. The results I am expecting are just the first draft of my job. I'm expecting a draft, not an accurate information because sometimes, like yesterday, I was asking the machine to understand the concept of manage app. Instead of searching google, I just chatGPT, manage app expert, explain what is manage app. A formal definition for example. If I don't know about the topic I'm researching I have to trust the tool. Sometimes I'm not sure if it's the correct behavior to just trust or if I should research again with other sources if the info is accurate. So that's the 50% of the time I'm searching, researching, validating. So that's my daily use of the tech, but I'm delighted, I love it.
column30: The best way I have to learn about chatGPT was to prepare a training a course I recorded one month ago to explain to the designers how to use chatGPT or AI to improve their skillset, the way they have to do the job. The training course is already online in Spanish. I was the teacher. Preparing the training course I had to try different prompts, had to research in the internet how the designers are experiencing with chatGPT and found a lot of people working on that. A lot of prompts, notion documents with a lot of prompts ready to work. And that's one of the paths I followed to learn and I was absolutely delighted. And in a different way, in tik tok. Don't ask me why because I don't know, the algorithm of tik tok has the answer, but I see more videos than expected of people talking about how to use chatGPT or other kinds of artificial intelligence to work as a product designer, to get the value as a product designer and for me, especially in tik tok, I learned how to ask. How to build a prompt, to get the tech ready to get better answers and for me it's absolutely amazing.
column31: The research I do with chatGPT is personal, in a professional way but personal. It's for me. I am the researcher but also the target. The results of my research I'll use on me and only me. I use the results of this research because mainly I use this tech to clarify concepts, to organize concepts or to extent a concept. To extent a topic. If I need more info, for example I have to do an abstract, okay, help me to do an abstract, give me 5 main ideas. This kind of use is the main for me. It's especially useful when I have to learn about a book, chatGPT can give me an abstract or for example - you are a librarian, tell me the 5 main ideas about a book or that person. For me it's useful, I have to recognize I would never give a public class or conference with that information because I'm not sure if it's accurate. I have my doubts. I don't have that doubt if I search on google, if I search on Google I trust the source. In the results space I choose the source and sources I can trust I know. But with chatGPT I don't have the way to understand if the info is accurate or not. I don't have any source to verify. That's why I use that info just for me. Then I will work and make decision. I would never publish something direct from chatGPT to the internet for example
column32: P believes that it can be used to help reduce the human working hours, and can help facilitate a 4 day work week.
column33: For now we don't talk much about this topic. We are starting, but only with the managers, not all the team because I showed them I did a training course for a client and it's online there's no coming back. We are speaking about how can take advantage of that tech to our processes. Not to run methodologies, but to organize our internal processes for now. But it's not a main conversation
column34: Not yet. M: do you see it being necessary at some point? P: I'm sure it will be because AI is getting main stream and I know in maybe weeks or months there will be people asking I want to do this or that. I'm sure we will need because there are 2 factors, on one side we have remote work, on the other side we have AI. There will be one day where the 2 factors will get together and as companies we need to do better management of the remote work. We will need to understand how can we take advantage of both factors. Maybe to work less in terms of traditional 8 hours per day work. As a company we have a goal to have the 4 days working week and maybe this kind of tech can help us reach that objective better. But not today, it's not a topic of conversation yet. But I'm sure this year maybe the Q2, Q3 it'll be a topic of conversation more than I'm trying to evangelize. It'll be a regular topic I'm sure.
column35: Not yet, but anticipates or hopes for one
column37: 5 because if I don't know the topic I would say 7 or 8. But I don't know the topic I don't criteria to understand if the information is accurate or not. If I know the topic, sometimes more and sometimes less than 5, but 5 is a good answer.
column39: Personally, 3-5 years ago, before the pandemic, I had the feeling that tech runs faster than me. I didn't have that feeling 10 or 15 years ago. The fact is AI is running faster than previous tech. Sometimes I feel like you have to hurry up or the train will go without you. But I feel absolutely comfortable in the middle of this stress because it reminds me my very first experience with the internet in 1997, 1996. When I was like "wow I can see the webpage of the Rolling Stones". We are not still on that conversation and there are 2 factors. I am not sure if they talk about that because I want to. Me and my managers, yes, but with the rest of the team I don't have visibility, I have visibility through the managers. Today this is not the conversation about hehe we can talk to the machine because in the news paper everyone is talking about that. But speaking on how big concepts on how to apply in the research methods, how to apply in the process of the company, how to react when a client asks what about AI for my project. We don't still have that conversation, but I'm sure this year we will have that conversation
column41: I don't know because the velocity of this topic is fast. Faster than I expected because 1 month ago, it was like wow it's a magic. But yesterday I was reading Adobe just released a tool to create images just prompting. I have no idea, but I'm sure in 2023, December 31 this year, I'm sure part of our professional life will be changed because of this tech. I'm not sure if we'll speak about all our professional lives, but some I'm sure.
column42: In general I'm a positive guy, so I tend to think about the positive aspects of using that technology.
column43:
M: what will you do next time you open chatGPT? P: depends because now I'm using chatGPT 4 which a little slower than the previous one. So I'm learning, it's difficult because I'm in chatGPT with a pencil and paper because I organize the way I ask, the way I design the prompt. I'm learning to prompt twice to get better results. Sometimes I imagine myself, the movie HER, sometimes I'm the guest star of HER because I need to think how to ask the tech. With google 20 years ago, I never think how to ask, I just ask. Now I need an additional layer of thinking for myself then ask the tech. Which is different than 20 years ago, because I have to make a significant effort to get better results. Before it was let's ask and google will do the magic, which is interesting because google did. We have that perception that google did because we have the info we needed. 

M: anything else? P: Not really, because every time I have an invitation to speak about AI we speak about the ethics, copyright, the legal problems. Like 20 years ago we had with napster and music, I thought you ask me that because you are young, we already had this discussion 20 years ago. You led the topic with different questions which is good for me. It was difficult for me because it's the first time I have this conversation in English, it's been a challenge for me.

column19: A client started talking about it at work, and was showing examples of what ChatGPT could do.
column20: When he was able to use Spanish in ChatGPT and it responded flawlessly back in Spanish.
column23: 50% of the time researching what it can do, 50% of the time "training" the technology to get a result. Did not answer rating question specifically, but has created training programs to teach about the potential uses of ChatGPT.
column30: Created a training course/taught a class on ChatGPT uses; While preparing the course, he tried many different prompts and internet searches from people that had used them successfully. Also found many videos about ChatGPT use on TikTok, states this was especially useful in learning how to build a prompt for better answers.
column31: Clarify and organize concepts, or to extend a topic. Has used ChatGPT to help build an abstract, or give ideas as a starting point. Uses it for summarization of large amounts of text, such as a book (will ask for 5 main points of the text).
column32: P believes that it can be used to help reduce the human working hours, and can help facilitate a 4 day work week.
column33: Has shared info and training course with managers, but the team is not using it. They are discussing how it can help to organize internal processes, but it "is not a main point of conversation yet."
column34: Not yet, but "I'm sure it will be necessary because artificial intelligence is getting mainstream" - Can see it being a topic of conversation by Q2 or Q3 of this year.
column35: Not yet, but anticipates or hopes for one
column36: Has concerns about the accuracy and trust of some topics, especially subjects that the participant does have much prior knowledge on. Notes that he trusts the results of Google more because he can see and verify the source, and trusts the information given on ChatGPT less because there is no way to verify where the information or answer came from.
column39: "I think that it can support research, I wouldn't be afraid that it will substitute researchers. It can support translation and analysis of a lot of data, but still, I don't think it could do a moderation, for example." Needs a human to understand context, non-verbal communication, final analysis/synthesis. "Things can go quicker, but I don't think it will replace the research itself."
column40: Moderated research, no. Un-moderated research, maybe
column41: "I don't know, it's really difficult."
column42: "For children right now, it could be quite dangerous"... "Smaller children don't know what is good and what is not good." "For myself, I see the positive side... new ways of working, shopping, connecting to people, so I'm really interested, but for children I see the negative side."

column6: Title is strategic director and it's difficult to say because I'm not an active researcher, but probably around 10 years of experience connected to research to some extent. It's still connected because I work with our researcher but I don't do sessions usually by myself.
column9: Probably mostly for work because in my spare time I prefer to spend time with family and kids and considering my kids' age, 2 and 8, I try to keep them out of the web for now. Even daughter who is 8, so this doesn't include streaming services or just watching something, but when it comes to internet as a way of interacting with information, for me it's mostly my work and besides that, some social media, some hobby stuff, reading some reviews of stuff I like and that's it.
column11: n/a
column12: n/a
column14: It's a difficult question because we're besides the point where we can make some influence around the nature of the media itself. But if I could focus on the safe side, I'm kind of aware of how people's mentality has changed because of this instant access to info, and I'm especially concerned with the younger generation and very little regulation concerning at what age can kids use certain services. This includes the internet and trend towards mobile devices. My personal view is that I would welcome more regulations made by countries to protect their kids. When it comes to adults, I also see a lot of symptoms of addiction and some wrong influence of both internet and mobile devices. But probably it's not something to regulate for adults. Besides that, the bad things I see mostly focus on both fake news and all the stuff around that but also the anxiety that social media produces both in terms of personal and work life. Where you look at linkedin and see all those success stories while you know most of them are not true but it still gets to you. The good things are obvious, the incredible speed of development of concepts that happens during... especially this year we can see that it's just building up every year. At what point you have to ask yourself, probably this is the point where you want to ask yourself where is the human element in this. Because if we as humans it's getting more and more difficult to catch up with the tech, then what's the point of the tech in the first place. I might be skipping questions, but yesterday there was the announcement from the copilot from microsoft and also google shows the automatic assistant is doing the work for you, building presentation based on simple description or other documents and I just imagine the other part where the robots create the presentation and sent it to you to a client or another stakeholder and the other stakeholder says to their copilot just read it and do the work. So you have to ask yourself what's the point of being human in all of that, so maybe we don't have to do any point at any point.
column15: In my mind there's a separation... I'm not an expert on that, but based on what I read in last couple of years, I'm separating the current products that were introduced in the last couple months and the future products and concepts of AI. When I think about the current situation, I think it's kind of a hype still and I think regardless of the... it's true that the poroducts that are already here will change the nature of many jobs and will need to introduced to, taken into account in many jobs. My feeling is it's going to be a turbulent time, I don't feel real fear or a strong anxiety because I still feel that the current products, chatGPT and the google ones and other ones are simply based on predicting... these are models that predict the next words that should appear in the document. It's very impressive, but it's still not the broad AI. But when it comes to general AI, this is a concept that could cause anxiety and fear and I still believe we're far from that. But thinking about that I'm concerned and believe it also should be regulated and should be developed with great care which we don't really see happening right now with the products we see. If you see the statements from open AI and Google, they say it's still kind of an experiment and we need help. They do some testing regarding the ethics and all the consequences but it's... I hope it's going to be an interesting learning experience for the future, when the real, really powerful models or products appear. Maybe this experience will help us be more prepared for the more dangerous products that will be created.
column23: Very low. My perspective is that it caught me off guard in December when I read abou the improvements. I decided, maybe I couldn't really take enough time to play with it. I see my team doing it, so we discuss it and try to find ways to use it in our work as well. Personally I decided I want to understand what deep learning is, and I'm reading a book about deep learning. It was published a couple of years ago so it's not up to date, but I think the concepts are pretty much the same and it's what led to chatgpt. What really interested me is to understand one thing to be impressed by the outcome of the product. I read an interesting opinion, I think by Noah Chomski, and he said he's not really a fan of deep learning. He said it's not really scientific but it's like engineering marvel, but because of the nature of deep learning, it's just this net that's not really well-thought of by humans. It's just the model that somehow generates the results. This was really interesting to me, so I decided to try to understand better how it works. Then I'm going to play with the prompts and so on.
column31: My opinion is not really... I didn't think it through well, just exploring it. I've seen some posts saying you can do UX research with just chatgpt and people playing with that. At this point I'll say, the translation is kind of the basic stuff, so it's not really crucial. I wonder if we could use... one thing we're looking for in Poland for example is the automatic transcription, because the current products don't work well enough for Polish language. I know it's been solved for English a long time ago and we've been trying the products once in a while but they didn't work for Polish well enough. It's probably not chatgpt, but it could be some plugins, this is a potential improvement. When it comes to doing research itself, I could imagine some unmoderated research testing being much more advanced with tools like chatgpt. And then you might wonder at what point you get used to those assistance and you add voice and add some avatars and you can do moderated testing with tools like that. But at this point I'm not really sure. I would prefer to believe that both in design and research, the human to human communication will be irreplaceable because it will actually work in a different way. We'll always be aware when talking to a machine. I remember Bob and Gavin talking about this during one of the conferences with Alexa we kind of change the way we talk to the machine because we know how to operate it. It might influence how we talk to other people as well with short comments and so on. But I hope it's always going to be a separate conversation whether I'm talking to a machine or human. It's why I believe that replace user researchers with cost effective AI or avatars or AI researchers will not happen soon or ever. But we'll see. Same for AI design, we've seen where you do a sketch and get a working website, but still it's like with computer generated images. If it's just a piece of content you want to put out quick, it's going to work for you, but if it's something that represents your brand, your unique relationship with customers or users, AI is not going to work well enough. Maybe as a proof of concept, but human eye and human ear will be able to distinguish the real thing, I hope for much longer.
column32:
Translation is basic, not really crucial

Auto transcription would be helpful bc current pdts don't work for Polish language

unmoderated testing could become more advanced w tools like chat gpt

Imagines adding voice and avatars to do moderated testing

Wants to believe that human-human connection will be irreplaceable bc we'll always be aware when talking to a machine; we change the way to talk when talking to Alexa; believes that replacing user research w cost effective AI researchers won't happen soon or never; same for design, AI will work for something to post quick but AI not good enough for branding or connecting
column33: As most of the teams in the creative space, our team plays with generating content, both text content and products like majourney, all the visual ones. I think in one or two research projects they tried out the translation options because I think it's also quite useful for translations. I remember they were very impressed with translations, especially in terms of Polish-English which is not perfect for now. M: has translation been an area that's challenging for using Google translate? P: I know the comment was that it's much better than Google translate.
column34: Not yet. I think if I was to impose any policy that would be that I would welcome the use any tools like that in our work flow that would help the efficiency of the services we provide, but I think the policy would be to inform the client, or whoever is receiving the outcome of the work that some tool was used to generate some content. I wouldn't imagine that we provide a report to a client and we say we did it while a machine did it. I think that's the thing that comes to my mind at this time. Probably there are more risks I'm not seeing right now but I think with the level of trust we have and the team I have which is not very big, I think that would be the main thing. Our relationship with the client.
column35: Not yet, but anticipates or hopes for one
column37: Both in terms of the quality of the insights or what it provides and the formal quality... in the context of the work we do? I would say about 5. I think it's... we can find there are applications of that in our work, and I hope my team finds some of them to not miss the train that is now traveling and speeding up, but I'm not... My strategy regarding our services our company is not to be dependent on products like that.
column41: I don't know if it's where we're going but I think it's going to be about the quality of the content and not the quantity. We got to a point where even humans are producing so much content, so it's very difficult. So I think maybe the machines... I'm not very impressed about machines creating more content that is convincing, but I would be impressed with machines helping us figure out which content is the most important one to digest for humans. I'm always thinking about life is speeding for all of us, but it's 24 hours for each human and it's not going to change ever. So the tech has eaten a lot of our mental space and a lot of that time, so being an optimist I hope and think it's not going to be about being able to produce any kind of content. It's not going to be of any value anymore because people want the time to consume that. I think supporting humans be very breif with communicating, I think that would be a better value. So I hope it's going to move in that direction as well. Right now I see we're all in awe, wow what those machines can do. Then you're going to ask yourself they can replicate a lot of things people do now, but if they can replicate them very quickly maybe there's no point in doing all of this. Like I said there's a machine to machine move that can happen, and just the key decisions can be taken by the human, as long as the human can really understand what's happening with the machines. And I think our understanding will have to grow and it's all about responsibility and education and so on. But if we come to a point where those systems act as tools such as... like if we take people from 1950s and show them a tool like figma, they will say it's pure magic and mindblowing, but to us it's just a tool supporting us. I hope the current wave of products may seem magical now, but maybe a few months or next year we're going to understand them better as tools and they're going to help us free some space, some creative space, some thinking space for something more valuable.
