column6: General manager, for working in the field, 10 years this year
column9: On a personal level, my entire life is on it. We're highly involved. Professionally, many of the systems we work on are not necessarily on the internet, they tend to be highly complex systems that tend to not be online. But we do quite a bit of user research focusing on webpages, so from all different directions.
column12: Yes, but to a point in the sense I like to keep myself open minded in terms of not become over specific in my knowledge. Keep a little perspective on how an average user would experience something. M: on scale of 1-10? P: 8 or 9
column14: Obviously the connectivity, it's unparalleled. The wealth of info, the ability to have the entire library of the universe at your fingertips. That's wonderful. The other side of it is, our community and society doesn't have the tools to monitor, to filter the info. So if you're talking to me on a personal note, not as a professional, anything from my children being exposed to content I wouldn't necessarily approve. We're constantly bombarded with information which is not necessarily... it has an impact even if you know it's not necessarily true. There's always the fake news aspect of it, but over time it's hard to avoid it having some impact. That would be ambivalent.
column15: I think that because I'm aware of the other side of, and I know sometimes what goes into the algorithm and the dataset, there's a little bit of mistrust going on. It's kind of this dangerous toy that's entered my house and I have to figure out am I going to play with it.
column17: Probably chatgpt although I'm not sure that's the exact definition
column19: I think we've been looking... I guess with Dali a year ago and then Dali 2 and now with chatgpt, there's a lot of buzz around it. I've heard the terms before, but in terms of common use and hitting the discussion those would be the 2 main
column20: Personally no, I don't think on a personal day to day use, in my private life not really. It sparked different discussions in the projects we're doing in terms of developing technologies and integrating these kinds of tech there. But I haven't been using them personally.
column21: 7 or 8
column23: We've played around with it in Israel. People tend to have decent English but not perfect. A lot of people tend to use it to bridge the gap just even in writing emails. One of our team members just posted on something on LinkedIn and challenged everyone to guess whether it was written by them or chatgpt. The Hebrew version of all this tech tend to be aweful. Even transcripts in Hebrew is always ridiculous to the point of being humoristic. It never really works in Hebrew the dataset is never big enough. M: same with chatgpt? P: yeah
column26: Personally I've just fooled around with it together. Haven't actually used for my personal needs. Found it stimulating, we tried to play around a little with Dali for fun, and I was surprised by the gap between the buzz in the media and what I was getting from it. So it seemed to be a little of a gap. M: less impressive? P: A lot less impressive, cause you hear all this buzz from the media and then trying to get images and just getting things that are garbled.
column30: Probably a mixture of looking it up on google maybe look for some articles. We've putting together a day with a lecturer which is probably going to be on that topic, we're looking to expand everyone's knowledge on that topic. M: that would a uni professor coming? P: Someone who specializes in it
column31: I think that language is an issue for Israelis. So anyone on my team who can improve the way they sound either in writing, it's almost like a shortcut, it's a little bit dangerous shortcut. We do a lot of documentation as well, so I hear employees say they'll use chatgpt help them write a summary. On the one hand I feel like maybe it'll help do the work more efficiently, but on the other hand I'm wary of having that not reviewed closely enough, or having that run away with us. So there's a mixture there. But I think in Israel, I see that with people who are super talented but English is a big barrier for them, so if that's something that could help you make that less of a barrier then I think that would be important. That would be on the one side. then I think that's the maybe the main, immediate use I can see on our end.
column32:
language, Can help with people who lack English skills

Have to be careful about what you're getting as far as information. There is a lot of mistrust, playing with it but its almost still a joke, not really incorporating it and getting a lot of gibberish, not gonna give a decent protocol QUOTE 12:33
column33: Yeah, definitely.
column34: No, we tend to be fairly loose in terms of letting people use whatever they need. We have internal guidelines for reviewing documents or anything that's delivered by our company which I haven't relaxed in any shape or form. I don't see it as anything that can replace, especially when it's something highly specific and professional. So I don't really see it as something that can replace. But I do see it as something that can help team members that don't have super high proficiency in English, just make their lives easier. As far as the source of info, we've been playing with that as well, just looking up and saying can you help me write this study protocol, I think the best analogy I've heard it's like a teenager, it's already grown, it looks big, you're tempted to treat it like an adult and then it goes and has an emotional breakdown. In the sense it looks like it's there, but then you have to be very careful and make sure what you're getting as far as information. I think everyone on our end is where I started at the beginning. There's a lot of mistrust, we're flirting and playing with it. Challenging it a little, maybe you can help us. It's almost still a joke, we're not really incorporating it. And we're getting a lot of gibberish, if you ask it to write a protocol you're not going to get a good protocol.
column35: Not yet, but anticipates or hopes for one
column37: I think it's at its most dangerous point because sometimes it's absolutely fine and sometimes it's absolutely not. I would give it a low confidence would not take it to client. 1 or 2, absolutely not trusting it. I think it's the worst possible place because it's very tempting. It's fine a lot of the time and then suddenly can give you something completely aweful.
column39: First I see a lot of research about how best to incorporate it into designing platforms. We see it not necessarily specific tools, but almost all my clients are at different phases of incorporating different aspects of AI into... We do a lot of medical, so if it's scanning medical records and maybe highlighting relevant info for your physician for your GP, that's a project that we did. We have these issues about how to design that in a way that maximizes the benefits without taking away the person's judgement call. You do want the physican to make the judgement call about what data they're going to be using. There's a lot of room for research about what people perceive and what the best way is to communicate what they're getting and not getting. I think the trickiest aspect is that on a lot of parameters it performs better than humans. I want that tool to scan my records cause it's going to give my doctor info that otherwise he's going to miss on the one hand. But it's going to miss info that a doctor won't miss. It makes different mistakes, unlike humans. Our ability to communicate the kind of monitoring the user is going to do on the output is a big challenge. I see research there on how people perceive it. In terms of incorporating into actual research practices, writing protocols, transcribing or having people do the research it as kind of an agent, I mean yeah, definitely. But I don't know if that's the most interesting aspect of it to me. The most interesting aspect is how we help people make the best out of the tech without losing their ability to monitor. You have to redefine your role as a decision maker when presented with data created from these kinds of sources. It's different. We have to create interfaces that support that. And I don't think anybody has really cracked the way to do that yet. So we're getting... I think a challenge from our side is to communicate that gap because we see the developers and tech community sort of in love with it and we have a challenge of communicating information we get from users in our research back to developers and say you're presenting them with this information and the users are perceiving it in a different way. Sometimes we see over trust, sometimes we see under. I don't think that the tech community is necessarily sensitive to how people perceive the output.
column41: That's a big question. I think it's going to be everywhere. It's already there and there's going to be more. We're kind of in a fork in the road in terms of are we going to be able to give the next generation of people tools to look at the output critically? I don't even know what those tools need to be yet. In the sense that when I'm getting info, because it's such a black box I don't know where it's coming from. If I had to give my 10 year old son some guidelines, you give it some text this is how you can evaluate whether it's relevant or not. Before it's easy, look for the source, check who said it, that's kind of old world guidelines. I think we need to define them and I hope that the regulation, also just the legal regulations of these things catches up. Otherwise we're going to see a lot of issues. And Israel is an interesting place, it's never quiet and simple here, politically as well. Everything is very immediate here. So it's worrisome to some extent.
column42: That's almost a personally trait question. I'm positive. At the end of the day I think, if I mentioned before with the internet, it's a ton of info bombarbed. These tools are basically answer how to synthesise the information. This is what we need to make sense mountain of info, obviously a human cannot do that. On the one hand it's almost a natural answer to this huge amount of data we now have. I'm optimistic, I think humans tend to fall on the right side of things, I hope. Keep our fingers crossed. M: you mentioned not having used it for personal use but played around with it a little? P: Yeah
column43:
M: any idea for the next thing you might want to pop into chatgpt? P: I think one area I haven't explored but did want to get around to do a little more is replacing the search options there, not just looking for text, but actually seeing if I'm looking for any actual information, how that comes back. And if that's a more useful or concise tool as opposed to google search which is the obvious default. If I'm just looking for any basic piece of info in my daily life, how that works out. 

M: anything else? P: Wasn't sure what you were going for, so I think this kind of met what we discussed. I am happy to roll it forward if you want me to run the interview by anyone on our end.

column6: Co-CEO, not a researcher, but as leading I'm more on the management side, but I'm quite close with the subject. Originally and IT engineer but I've always been close with the interface and interactions and human machine interactions
column9: It's something I can't live without. I'm very digital.
column12: Yeah, definitely. 9, not 10 because I'm not ever a first adopter, but I'm the next adopter.
column14: What I like with the internet is accessing whatever I want and communicating with people wherever they are very easily. What I don't like is people to get lazy and only communicating online when they can have more humkan interaction. And all the side effects of this, things like not having the courage to say something face to face. Maybe they are keyboard very reactive people. But mostly I love it. I'm not on the side of the ones that mostly criticize. I think this is one of the best things humans created
column15: I'm an IT engineer so I'm always eager to understand the next breakthrough, the next gadget, the next possible capability of any tech. So I'm very curious on what tech can do for people. So I try things a lot, but I'm not a first adopter in the sense I don't enjoy tech that are mostly faulty. But as fast as it becomes useful I'm there. Having said that, the AI is... I have a very clear opinion. In the 90s when I graduated, my university offered a branch of my graduation called "the artificial intelligence". So at that point, it already seemed very attractive. I didn't take that branch of the course but I followed whatever happened in terms of AI since. My opinion is that until I saw chatgpt, it was very clear to me that most of the population over expected what the tech could actually offer. The name AI is very misguiding. It was not intelligent, for me. Siri is a huge disappointment, Alexa as well. I could see the evolution of the tech, but it was never very useful. But with chatgpt I think it definitely changed. When I saw that I told my wife, you need to see this. So that's what I think, that chatgpt is a step that we will remember for a long long time.
column20: I'm very much in all the podcasts and news so I can't really recall the first time I read chatgpt, but it was clearly in the first 24 hours I think that most tech people saw it. And I read about it, I saw the promise and it can chat about any subject in human or natural language way. I went on, registered and tried it. I have no idea what I asked, but I immediately saw it was something very different
column25: It's not that I used it intensely from that point till today but I guess I asked a few things about the world soccer games and things like that. I definitely saw the huge difference between google search and that. So natural language is something that I care about a lot and one interesting point is that I'm portuguese and I always feel like we will get whatever tech in English first, a few other languages and maybe then in Portuguese, but in Brazilian Portuguese. It's always first Brazilian Portuguese because they are 200 million and we are 10 million and there's a huge difference between the 2, a wider difference than UK and US English. So the second thing I tried was in European Portuguese and it mostly worked, not perfectly but it was a double excitement. It worked 100% in Brazilian Portuguese and 90% in European Portuguese so I was quite amazed with that. One thing I was also surprised was I was searching for a drop down box to choose the language, "where do I change the language to Portuguese" and then I did what I thought it was and asked do you speak Portuguese and the conversation kept coming on, so I'm impressed.
column30: I tend to be look at the news or a number of podcasts. So while I drive or walk, I go to places like Wall Street or tech news of the day, maybe some Portuguese podcasts as well. When I want to dive in I just google things. At this point I either google or chatgpt things.
column31: We started that internal conversation. We are not only a research organization, we're research and design. I think it will help on some tasks, it will make some tasks much faster like transcripts. That's not much, but for maybe organizing scripts, maybe creating or specifying simple designs, write me a design specification for bank app to access my account or blablabla. It will do that very easily, it'll save a lot of time, but at the same time it will bring the value of simple human tasks to 0. So we'll have to see how our professional services will evolve in terms of their market value. I think it will have a learning curve and I'm not thinking of chatgpt alone, this is just a showcase of the technology, we'll see many other applications. I haven't tried the new bing, but we'll see many other applications that are not chat or chatbox that are other things inside our applications, new applications we don't yet know about. So I think some of the things we do everyday will be automatically done by this kind of tech. Even design things, chatgpt works with text but there are a number AI applications with image like mijourney and things like that. So it's easy to understand that whatever is kind of simple or not going to use a lot of creativity, critical thinking, strategic thinking. A lot of what's not in that pocket will be quite easy to generate. I think we'll see an explosion of applications of this as we've seen in other ways of innovation like mobile or personal computing in the 80s, 90s, or mobile computing in the early 2000s. At some point we saw a big explosion of new applications, that's what we'll see. And in out field, we'll see the figmas and adobes of the world to be able to incorporate those kinds of tech to make our work easier on one side but not billable on the other.
column32: will make some tasks much faster- transcripts; organizing scripts; creating or specifying simple designs; Example- write design specs for bank app to access accounts; will save a lot of time; it will bring value of simple human tasks close to zero; some services will change in market value; will have a learning curve; will see many other applications that are not chatbots; some things we do everyday will be done by this tech, even design things; there are AI apps with images like midjourney and things like that; simple things or without creativity or critical or strategic thinking will be easy to generate; will see explosion of applications of this like with mobile computing or personal computing in 80s and 90s, early 2000s; will see Figma and Adobe incorporate this tech to make job easier but not billable
column33: Yeah. Maybe for now only up to a certain level. My head of marketing always goes to chatgpt to translate text to English or to improve our English level or to generate a list of topics for blablabla, so she's a heavy user. I'm starting to see people use it in research, for instance to improve a script
column34: No. We're at the point in which we just need to understand how far it goes. Any limits on that we haven't set any yet.
column35: Not yet, but anticipates or hopes for one
column37: It depends. We all know that it technically hallucinates. It invents facts if they are probable but unfortunately untrue. If there's a probability that fact will be true it says this is a fact. It makes things up if they are probable. But in tasks like improving text I just translated but I'm not very good in English, I think that's very good. So language is definitely something in which it's very good.
column39: I don't think it's still clear but understanding where you should go... if you're in the beginning of the career you need to understand the basics, how do people do things. That's going to be really fast with this kind of tech, you just need to learn how to ask as we all learned how to search in google. Searching is a skill we all have been working on for a few years, we're just going to develop something similar which is how to ask. So maybe I have a problem and I'm not rationalizing my problem. If I know I have that AI tool close enough, I'll make the effort to make my problem rationally in my head so I can ask and can have an answer. So we'll develop that kind of skill but the improvement will be faster because it's not only having the info at an arm's length, it's having the knowledge at an arm's length. So it's not information, it's knowledge. The reason I don't yet use chatgpt everyday every time it's because many times I don't realize I can use it. I'm thinking about something, for instance I was thinking about a new device I've installed in my garden to measure the moisture of the ground to a watering device and I kept thinking about that and a couple days ago I said I can ask chatgpt about it. I did and the questions I had which I had been able to google in a distant and thorough way, I got answers, very organized answers. I still need to check them in case they are not just hallucinations. We still need at this point to have a very critical thinking on what we get. But if I read correctly what's coming next, they will reduce the level of possible hallucinations very fast, so I think my mother will trust this kind of tool completely.
column40: Absolutely. If you imagine that kind of bread and butter project that you can perform in automatic tools that will generate scripts for people to go through and get small rewards, yes. I think the whole process can be automated, yes. Please search this and that in that kind of field, yes. If it's bread and butter I would say yes. Probably you still need to supervise, to give the best inputs but I think if it's bread and butter mostly, sure. But on the other side, maybe we can aspire to have deeper studies that are composed of a number of smaller studies or things that relate one to the others. Maybe we can go much further. Maybe the business still is there for much deeper or frequent studies. I always felt that researching is something that we scratch the surface and we can customers to pay that scratching. We could've always gone much deeper, so maybe this tech helps us sell deeper studies.
column41: I know we will use them the tools more and more. I think they will be more and more human like, not in the shape but in things like how would a human advisor help me on these tasks. Is it something I ask that's a chatbox, maybe we're going to have voice, that's easy, chatbox plus Alexa. Question-answer is one easy way of doing that, but we'll see others, so maybe things like unsolicited advise. Something like if I had a friend behind me all the time. And more and more in specific tasks, if I'm a musician in a way that really makes sense to me, if I'm an engineer in a way that makes sense to me. So integrated in the tools I use in the way I feel more comfotable with. So if it's advise, if it's questions, if it's warnings, suggestions or something that the tech sees I'm going to do, a promptive advise at that specific point saying "you can do it better and faster with this". People will find ways of having the tech be present without me exactly soliciting the specific help. I think that will make sense to be available.
column42: That's an everlasting question. Ethics and that side of tech and so on, the point in my view is that the human being has always been improving in terms of technology. The main problem now is the speed. We have been exposed to many technologies before and the reason why we're so afraid of that side of things is because of the speed of innovation. We're still humans, we're trained in acquiring and understanding technology, much better than our parents and grandparents, but still there's a limit. I think it's totally normal that we question the pros and cons of new technology and make a festival that it's going to be dreadful. The technology will mean the end of humanity, tha's normal in every technology. The question is that we haven't had time to finalize in the previous tech and we have a huge tech news that's going to explode that feeling. I'm very optimistic on tech. We humans will find the good ways of using tech. Of course we need to take care, but that's human invention as well. That's cat and mouse. We will be able to find the dangers and to prevent them. I'm thinking in general terms, I'm not talking of nuclear bombs. So yes, I think the turmoil has just started in terms of the dangers of generative AI. We're going to listen and read a lot about that. I'm very... it's very funny to see my daughters telling me that "dad I used chatgpt to do my English homework" and I'm like "brilliant, that's it. Understand it, go through it". No it's not a problem, I don't want their school to prohibit that and decide you cannot use it. It's the opposite, I think it's very good that they try it, understand it, they become very demanding on what it does. It reminds me of the times in the 90s in which the teachers were not savvy enough in terms of tech to understand that the calculator I was taking to the exams was not doing only sums. There was a lot more knowledge inside them. That was very good, that kind of steps are very good. I'm not on the side of people who forbid.
column43:
M: what do next time you open chatgpt? P: I think I need to think of my hobbies and of the long lasting questions I have and review them and think which ones can I solve immediately. If not before, in case I need it professionally. 

M: anything else? P: No, we covered a lot, this is a great topic, we could spend the rest of the day here.

column6: UX/User experience director, been working in the field of UX since 2002, this is my 21st year. Started from UX domain but also has a tutor, examiner, giving guidance to UX design projects as well. Still acting as a UX researcher and managing and directing UX design projects. And teaching as part time tutor in universities.
column9: I'm one of the early users and adopters of internet because when I started university in 1992, internet also arrived to Turkey. The main provider in Turkey was our university campus, that's why I had very early... I had very good connection to internet because the university had modem rooms and we had IDM machines 1390. At that time internet was not based on user interfaces so had to learn Unix. Experienced very early GUI, we had atavista, we didn't have google yet. What we had to do was FTP, the only transferring method was FTP. First I rejected those easy GUI but then I had to accept it. So I'm very early user, in 1996 or 7 I built my own website using HTLM. I always try to use or learn about social media as well. We didn't have social media, but we had some products of google. Through google we could create our own websites, but we didn't have social media, but could create our own webpages and interact with people by creating content. We had to design our own homepage layout but with the introduction of of facebook we started to have printed layout, we didn't have to design ourselves. I'm still using internet.
column12: Yes, I am. I'm not writing code, but in 87 my father bought me a comodor 64 with the basic programming language. I learned that and started to make small code. And then in secondary school I learned about pascal coding language and learned a little C++, a little java and some php because during my phd I needed to design an online questionnaire. I think we had survey monkey but very limited, so I had to design my own online questionnaire tool, so I had to code it myself and the interface. I did my masters degree in physics, so already some technical person and in my masters degree I had to write a code to simulate a temperature distribution and coded it in 4tron. So I'm always in tech but I find myself more comfortable and happy doing research on human side. That's why I left physics, so I switched to soft science. [rates myself as] 8
column15: I'm very much into... I'm very happy about AI because I was very curious about machine learning and thinking computers to think. During my phd I collected lots of data and to analyze data we have classical statistical methods, but these methods, when you give data to those classical methods, they make lots of... you have to play with your data in order to use those statistical models because they ignore things, they don't learn. Then I heard about a guy who was doing... at that time it wasn't called machine learning, he was doing soft computing because you're not computing with exact data. Cause feeling, thinking, liking something was not an exact data, you have to talk about % and intervals, like you're asking me from 1-10, you try to quantify the data by asking those questions. When I feed the computer with this data it also tries to think about these numbers and tries to define soft knowledge within the intervals and that tries to learn the data and give an answer. But it doesn't ignore any point in the data space. So it looks point and tries to understand, tries to create some pattern. This was exciting for me, so I also wrote some codes. It's called SOM, self organizing maps, so you give the data to the computer and write those SOM codes and it makes clusters and tries to relate those clusters to each other. The computer learns and it's very exciting for me because my first experience, personal experience with sort of machine learning. Whether it's AI, the machine learns and it creates AI. So I was very curious about it. And in recent years, because the machine learning people or AI scientists create an algorithm and the computer power increase immensely, they discovered that instead of using CPU they could use GPU - graphical processing unit - because then you can make a parallel process in the data, so it increased the power of the computer. So it became quite popular and then I was amazed with the story of deep mines. Because we were witnessing the mental computer competition like deep blue. Chess has a lot of rules and you have to think about a lot of possibilities and computer is learning all these prossibilities and at that time the computer power, because they used super computers, made lots of calculations and make chess movements. But then in deep mines, they beat the go world champion and it was amazing because go has very... compared to chess, very simple rules, very few rules and endless possibilities. So it showed the power of and the level of artificial intelligence. And recently we came across chatgpt, it's amazing. I heard about it and a couple of weeks ago we had a meeting with one of our clients and the client told us he does lots of things with chatgpt. He said even I don't write standard reports anymore, I give it to chatgpt and it writes me a report. And then I was very curious and was amazed by what it did. My wife is a professor at a university and gives homework to students, so I told her just give me homework that I'm not aware of and then I'll show you my output. She gave me stuff I'm not aware of and I gave it to chatgpt and it created a report that my wife was also surprised and excited and she told me that she could also use chatgpt help her write her scientific paper. Two days ago I'm tired but I'm happy tired cause we had amazing moments in south of Antalia. One of our clients is owner of 4 big hotels, one golf center, the second biggest golf area of europe and a very big sports arena. All the sports people from all over the world come there for their training and they have rehabilitation centers. And one of American hockey player, he's second best in the states for his region, he was injured and he found this place and came here and stayed there for a month for recovery. They're trying to do some mobile education for people who spent time there. We are going to do the UX research and design. One of the patterns in this project is the software person who is going to code all these designs. He's also an expert in chatgpt and open AI. He's going to give a webinar and his idea is we're putting all these menus and contact, but he says instead we should put chatgpt. He also showed us the results of his gpt research, so we're discussing whether... we're not sure yet, we're in the design process. Today in mobile applications or websites we have this chatbox. Whether this chatbox will be powered by chatgpt only when you ask or we have information architecture and navigation design, some people navigate through your interface or some people just use the search. It will act like the search function, but it will be more. We're just trying to learn how to... we have to also learn about chatgpt 4, it also creates visual content. First we have to learn how chatgpt, because it is AI, it will learn and I believe it will update itself every now and then. So we learn and learn and learn its power. I'm trying to imagine the feature interfaces with the introduction of chatgpt. Maybe based on your interactions it will personalize the interface based on you and the interactions with you. We have to discuss if we should give fixed layout to users or let the user interact with chatgpt and chatgpt or open AI... It will also update the layout design accordingly through interaction with the user and chatgpt. We are very excited, I'm very excited and very happy that I'm going to work with technical people who can achieve it. Because if those technical people are not there, as UX people we are just imagining and it's not being tested or produced. Of course we always do wizard of oz techniques and we can always create prototype as if it is working in AI but inside we will have opportunity. On the other hand I'm also excited and curious about blockchain tech. In this research we're going to apply both. So a centralized blockchain technology plus AI. These are the buzz words. As UX people we are at a time of a sort of evolution and we will also see whether we are necessary or not.
column21: 10 - very much interested
column23: 9 because I know how it works, I interacted with it. I know the theory behind, I try to read scientific papers on the math but they always start with the final equation, so you have to go back to textbooks to learn how those equations are generated.
column30: Community platforms, I would look through my own discipline first, how it is being applied in user experience community. But I would also be in contact with technical people, how they code. When they talk to us, they think we are soft people and they find it difficult to explain but I always mention that I have a physics background, I also played with some machine learning algorithms. I speak their language so I appreciate what they do and we are doing what is missing in the domain because we are designing the interaction with the human side. After a while they start to talk. I'm going to go through Youtube, watching videos about it, visit the website for my university because I know experts in our university. I'll look at MIT open source, all sorts of data. If I'm curious. I'm an old school reader, book reader. I like books a lot. For information seeking I use every means. Even in social, if I discover that someone is expert I say I can google them, but I want to hear it from you.
column31: Just trying to learn about ChatGPT 4, it will update itself now and then and will continuously learned. trying to imagine interfaces with integration of chatgpt and how can personalize interface based on interaction, should give fixed layouts or let user interact with ChatGPT and update layout accordingly
column32: I don't see any disadvantages. for example like dystopias and humanities, I leave it to philosophers. The good use of it, with good intentions and good planning... if it will give harm to my own protection then I have to regenerate myself. Because I did it in my life, I'm not afraid of changing, learning new skills because... we did with industrial revolution, same thing. These are the breakdowns in human evolution. This is one of the points we will have a breakdown but we will regenerate ourselves. I once read a book about those unemployed or fired IBM computer people, how some of them broke but some of them tried to learn new skills. I think I'll be one of those who's going to learn new skills because I'm always... I bought some electronic kits trying to learn something about IOT. I don't see any disadvantage. Of course there will be a negative impact because it's a breakdown point but we are still in the spiral of teasers on to teasers.
column35: N/A
column41: First off it will change, it will have a big impact on education. Not classical but today's education will be quite... generative AI will have a big impact on education. And on medicine. Maybe new diseases will be discovered but also new recovery techniques and new medicines will be discovered. M: what about your industry? P: yeah, the example I gave you, we will see in a couple of months how it will have an impact on the projects we do. It will be quite fast. People will understand what... we have this generative AI for a while, but chatgpt is a product and they're already based on previous research. Now I feel late adapter after I saw people start to use it. I feel I was a late adapter. This was for personal usage like creating reports or homework, I realized that chatgpt is more powerful than google because in google you search something and google gives you links to information, you go into the info and read it and digest it, but chatgpt creates... I write "write me a short survey about this and this", for example last week, once I had a humidic sensor and connected it to arduino and found a code to measure the humidity in the environment. But I had to search for that code in google, then I typed in chatgpt "write a code for humidity measuring with arduino" and it wrote a code and explained the code. "You should use this sensor, in order to get the input you should do this and that and connect it in such a way". It didn't give me any visual but with chatgpt 4 it will also create a visual for me. So it's much more powerful than google search. I think it will have such an... on a personal level I already realized its impact and it's evolution and in the short term I think we will see how it will impact our industry and how we will start to design, not interfaces, but interactions. Not only interface design, but interaction design will also change. In 6 months I believe we will... especially in our company we will see the impact of generative AI. We'll see whether people will accept it or not, but we will see the impact.

M: what about for your company?
P: they will see in a couple of months how gen ai will have an impact on their projects, chat gpt 4 are products that are already based on previous research; feels like a late adopter after seeing other people use it, chat gpt is more powerful than google bc in google you search and google gives you links to info that you have to go into and read but chat gpt creates (short survey)

For example, he has a humidity sensor for gardening and had to search for the code in google, he asked chat gpt to write a code for that and chat gpt wrote the code then explained it to him- much more powerful than google search

on a personal level, he has already realized chat gpt's impact. In the short term will see how chat gpt impacts the industry and how we will design interactions

In 6 months, his company will see the impact of gen ai, whether it will be useful and accepted or not
column42: n/a
column43: n/a

column6: Senior UX research consultant, 3-4 years experience
column9: I think the internet is an essential part of my life. With work and how I connect with people, how you consume entertainment. I guess it's such a huge part of your life now. Especially with the pandemic we all work remotely and with all the content like social media, I'm pretty sure I can say I cannot live without the internet now
column12: Yes. 8 because I use social media, all the tools that help me for work, but it's not to the point I create something or coding and stuff.
column14: What I like is how easy it is to search for information. It's very instantaneous, like where you want to go or where you want to eat. But also it's a curse as well, in a way it makes you lazy. I think internet, especially social media there's a harm for it, like you see all these highlights of these good things that happen in people's lives and sometimes it can make you feel insecure looking at all this social media. But also it's a source of information because you know some new fact or information from that. It's a blessing and a curse I'd say.
column15: It's very tech advanced. It's just like work, very unfamiliar for me
column17: It's giving you an instant result of something, that's what comes to my mind.
column19: From scrolling social media. I follow tech platforms and it was like "the gen AI is coming" and it talks about chatgdp and dali and all these different tools. I remember scrolling on social media and read the news, so it was mostly online. M: how far ago did you hear about this? P: I remember early last year, it started getting a buzz around it. A few content creators playing around with this gen AI M: 2022? P: yeah, early 2022
column20: I got really curious because I saw the content it's creating. I remember there was this content creator, she created the first cosmopolitan cover with the first cover made by Dali, then I got curious about it. I ended up registering, I just want to try. She talked about how it took her like 400 prompts to actually land that cover. It got me curious and I think I signed up for it, like I just want to try and if I write different prompts what would show up, M: what did you think about that? P: I think there's still this gap because when you write a prompt you have this mental image or visual, I remember typing "a dog walking at night" and you have this expectation the image will look like this and when it pops up it doesn't, it looks a bit not as expected and it made me feel like maybe I'm not a good prompt writer. You have to be very specific and I looked at how people are writing their prompts "Oh it has to be a Van Gaugh style painting". It got me thinking there's going to be this new job creation where it's like a prompt, specifically a Dali prompt writer, so it got me thinking about these things.
column21: 7 to 6. I think I'm interested but I want to learn, not just for Dali, I want to learn what is out there. With gen AI there's a lot of things, you can make prompts for videos. I want to assess which of these platforms will be most beneficial on helping me to work or have fun.
column23: M: has view of internet changed? P: I think not so much, it's just an additional fun thing to experiment. I remember I thought about actually you can use Dali to find something as simple as your presentation. Maybe sometimes you are doing an interview and you want to describe the household context of the respondent and you don't have a picture you can try Dali. That's what happened but the image turned out very robotic, it felt it wasn't very human yet. I was questioning I need to write a better prompt, I don't think it's going to work out if I want to use this tech yet for my work. Or maybe how could I educate myself to write a better prompt so that the tech can help me for work. I was toying around with the idea, but I haven't really used it as frequently as I wanted to, because there's still some gap of knowledge on how to use it in an efficient and good way.
column30: I haven't really gone to that point yet, but I'm pretty sure if I go like "how to write a better prompt in Dali or chatgpt" I'm sure there'll be lots of tutorials. Or I remember on LinkedIn a lot of people making this content like "21 ways you can maximize your chatgpt". So I was like "a lot of people have been educating us about this". But I haven't really thought about it, I haven't searched about it yet, but I know it's out there and if I want to search it one day, a lot of people are making tutorial on how to write a better prompt or how to use it efficiently for UX research for example
column31: I remember trying chatgpt and it can help you write a resarch background, like write me a quick summary of this project maybe. I thought to myself "maybe chatgpt can help us to do that" and just last week I was participating in Jakarta service jam and we have to submit our... I was a mentor in that project and the group had to submit what is this idea we created. The group start using, because we had such a short amount of time, "oh just use chatgpt to make just a quick, catchy caption". When we have a short window of time it can help us generate a quick thing. Not a complex thing, I feel like how to make a better project timeline or administrative work it can help us. And as a researcher we can focus on solving the complex things or things we need more discussion with our peers.
column32: After you emailed me, it got me thinking about downside. It's a good thing we can outsource this administrative work, but it got me thinking about the future researcher, because even though those tasks are boring, what if the future researcher don't have the basic things they have to do. It got me thinking about the future batch of researchers. It also makes us, not lazy, but maybe trying to find a balance between which job should researchers focus on and where can we use it in companion to how we work
column33: Not completely, we talk about it. We're using discord and we have this water cooler channel, we start talking about "you know adobe is releasing this new thing". We started talking about it, but we haven't really toyed around as a company. I know a lot of people in the company already knows about this, but we haven't gotten to the point where let's start experimenting with our projects. It's more an individual initiative.
column34: not yet anticipates I think regulations should be in place. Like I said it feels unethical. Not just in research agency like us, but in other companies and other industries there should be a set of rules or regulations like to what extent those gen AI are helping us in our work. I feel like, what if all this UX research agency are using it and then we have the same brief, what if the results are the same thing? All these gen AI are being fed with millions of data there'll be the probability that the result might be the same. Got me thinking there should be set rules or a guidebook, either in the company itself or maybe some sort of UX alliance can make principles or something.
column35: Not yet, but anticipates or hopes for one
column37: I've only used it a couple times, I feel I've tried so many prompts. I still feel you have to polish it, so I give it 7 or 6. The results that come out of the gen AI is a good basis, but the caption or description is not good enough or accurate enough, so you still become the human editor at the end. So it's like outsourcing the basic thing. You have this paragraph, but then, yeah. I don't want to submit my work blindly on what the AI is doing.
column39: I think it's not so much that... for every new tech there's always this fear that they're going to be replaced, certain jobs will be dropped. I want to see it in a positive way, how this tech can enhance our work and help us have more time to learn about new things. I wouldn't say UX researchers job will be obsolete in 5 or 10 years, but maybe our role will be transforming or maybe there's going to be a new set of skills we need to adopt. If transcription or basic administrative things is being taken care of by AI then UX researchers can focus more on the synthesis side or how can we challenge the output given to us by AI. Confident our role will still be there, it's not going to be replaced, but it's like we're working hand in hand. I'm thinking about this non-dystopian thing
column40: I don't think so. I still feel like even though at the end the companies are perfecting all the results coming out, I feel as a researcher I feel responsibility, I own this project, I still need to be the one managing it. I think the question is about feeling unethical, because imagine if all the research you plan out is being created by this gen AI, is it really your work or not? It feels unethical.
column41: Starting from 6 months, I would say companies will start learning about how to use it and how to implement, what the best to implement it. Maybe we can assess it like actually we have a lot of problems translating or moving visually when notetaking, we do it verbatim and then moving it to the capture sheet. I guess companies should assess which part of the research process needs gen AI the most. In 5 years, I guess that's how I would see it, then in 5 years we'll still keep adding on how we can use it, but in tandem. I would still feel like they are helping us, not to the point they are taking over our jobs. I do still believe that UX researchers, we have the knowledge, like a cultural nuance, but something that AI won't be able to capture that. That's the reason why humans are still, when doing interviews it's going to be different than how AI interviews. Even though maybe they're going to perfect how the AI is talking, it doesn't sound very robotic, but cultural nuance and capturing micro things on respondents lives, it's something only humans can still do, not AI yet.
column42: I can actually picture 2 sides because I feel with gen AI, I don't think the regulations or the set of ethics are still in place yet. I feel like all these AI are moving forward very rapidly, but the intervention on goverment side isn't still in place yet. If in rules and regulations are still not set in stone yet, then we could go on into dystopian road. For example, recently I used this app called lanza where everyone is taking their profile pictures, they're stealing the artists' work. That's one example of ethics. To what extent, they're learning from the artist, but they're stealing from it. But there's also this not so dystopian, where we go hand in hand and they're helping them. I guess I'm more on the dystopian side. althought her is a glimmer of hope, I believe that with every new tech it should help us, but seeing what's happening right now and how different companies are doing it. I have a feeling they don't think about the unintended consequences when releasing all this gen AI, that's why we hear about all these different problems, like they're stealing artist's work and it's also harming different users.
column43:
M: What is the next thing you'd do with chatgpt or dali? P: I just want to use it for entertainment for now. I haven't seen to the point... I still want to wait for the next version of how they perfect it. I feel like now it's still in beta mode for work, so I'm not going to trust or outsource my work to gen AI now. But maybe something to sate my curiosity around it. Like different kinds of art or stories. I think it's more on my personal experimentation rather than it's going to be helping me for work right now. 

M: anything else? P: I guess this conversation sparked me. Like where do we sit right now as a UX researcher with all this tech. My reflection is how we cannot just say do the normal method because we need to reeducate ourselves again. Trying to find gaps or to what extent they can help us, but is there anything that this tech enables to do. I remember thinking "robots can't replace creativity" but look what happened, dali and adobe it's like the first thing that comes up is like "oh shit". So it's like artists can be replaced in a just a snap like that, it's very unpredictable, so I feel like as UX researchers, how can we deal with the uncertainty and look for different ways to scale up or trying to make ourselves relevant even though there's going to be new tech coming in.

column41:
I think in 6 months, 1 year this AI would improve but still not being part of our daily lives. But definitely, within five years I could see that happening and of course, 10 years it's just like another tool everyone uses. Not further than 5 years from now, we should all be using AI.

M: As a researcher and beyond, how would AI be in your world? P: As a researcher I think it will be a great tool for analysis and for finding patterns and bigger data base than we can handle. For instance, if you take a week or 2 to find patterns in 20-30 interviews, these tools could do it almost instantly maybe. I think that would really speed up our work and help us improve our deadlines and everything. M: are we doing 10x as many projects then? P: Maybe, hopefully M: would the budget be different? P: I don't know, that's really interesting, I'm not involved in budgeting yet but I don't know, probably. Depends on how expensive that tool is, but I'm not sure.
